conversation.text: What did you want to make?
I would like to make Roast Pork Leg but I am having trouble understanding
Are you having trouble with step 1?
Yes, I don't know what temperature to pre-heat my oven to
You can either preheat your oven to 465 °F or 241 °C)
What do I do after preheating the oven?
After preheating the oven, you should score the surface of your pork leg. Use a chefs knife and score diagonal lines across the top of the meat while leaving an inch between each line.
evidence: sing a smooth chef's knife, score diagonal lines on top of the meat in a vertical pattern, taking care that each is spaced about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from each other.

conversation.text: How will I know when I have scored the leg enough?
When the leg has a crosshatch pattern across the whole leg, you are able to proceed.
evidence: fterward, repeat the process with diagonal lines in the opposite direction to create a crosshatch pattern.

conversation.text: Should the salt be scattered evenly throughout the leg?
The sea salt should be scattered across the entire scored area.
evidence: followed by 1 teaspoon (5.69 grams) of sea salt.

conversation.text: Ok I see, thank you
If you have completed the salting and oiling process, you can move onto roasting the pork leg. Put the pan in the top rack and keep the door closed until 25 minutes has passed.
evidence: Place your roasting pan onto the top oven rack. Keep the oven door closed and don't open it until 25 minutes has passed. After 25 minutes, check the skin to make sure it is crisp and golden in color. If it isn't, continue roasting your pork leg in 5- to 10-minute intervals until it is.

conversation.text: Can you tell me if the pork leg is ready?
Is the leg crisp and golden yet? If not, continue roasting it in 5-10 minute intervals.
evidence: After 25 minutes, check the skin to make sure it is crisp and golden in color. If it isn't, continue roasting your pork leg in 5- to 10-minute intervals until it is.

conversation.text: Should I continue roasting it after it is golden?
Yes you should. Roast according to how heavy the meat is, and use a meat thermometer to check if you are unsure.
evidence: After reducing the temperature, continue roasting the pork leg for 30 minutes per 2.2 pounds (1.00 kg). In this case, the pork leg is 4.4 pounds (2.0 kg), which means you should cook it for another 1 hour. Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the pork—it should read 160 °F (71 °C) when the pork is done. If you like your pork a bit crispy, cook it for 35 minutes per 2.2 pounds (1.00 kg), which is another 1 hour and 10 minutes for a 4.4 lb (2.0 kg) roast.

conversation.text: What do I do once the meat is cooked?
Is your meat reading at 160 degrees F?
evidence: Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the pork—it should read 160 °F (71 °C) when the pork is done. If you like your pork a bit crispy, cook it for 35 minutes per 2.2 pounds (1.00 kg), which is another 1 hour and 10 minutes for a 4.4 lb (2.0 kg) roast.

conversation.text: Yes it is reading at that temperature
Do you still need help with proceeding?
evidence: Remove the roasting pan from the oven, cover it with aluminum foil, and let it sit.

conversation.text: Yes I would like to move on. Could you tell me what to do next?
Cool the pork leg down for 10 minutes and serve.
evidence: Remove the roasting pan from the oven, cover it with aluminum foil, and let it sit.

conversation.text: What are some possible ways of eating the pork leg?
Would you prefer a sweet or a salty serving method?
evidence: Once it has cooled, slice it into 1 to 2 inch (2.5 to 5.1 cm) pieces and serve it with your choice of sides—pumpkin, roasted potato, steamed vegetables, apple jelly, and gravy are all great choices. Store your leftover pork covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 2 to 3 months.

conversation.text: Salty please. I am serving it at a family dinner
You can serve it with your choice of sides which could include pumpkin, potatoes, vegetables, or even gravy.
evidence: pumpkin, roasted potato, steamed vegetables, apple jelly, and gravy are all great choices. Store your leftover pork covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 2 to 3 months.

conversation.text: Ok I see. Can I store it in the freezer?
How long did you want to freeze it for?
evidence: Store your leftover pork covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 2 to 3 months.

conversation.text: I would like to freeze it for 3 months
You can freeze it for up to 2-3 months
evidence: Store your leftover pork covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 2 to 3 months.

conversation.text: Ok I see. thank you for your help
Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.
Thank you for your help it is greatly appreciated

procedure.description: Electric ovens take between 10 to 15 minutes to preheat, while gas ovens take about 5 to 10 minutes. Be sure to place the oven rack into the highest position before turning it on. Use an oven thermometer if you have one—it's a more accurate measurement of internal oven temperature.

procedure.summary: Score the surface of your pork leg.
procedure.description: Place your 4 pounds (1.8 kg) of pork leg into a shallow roasting pan. Using a smooth chef's knife, score diagonal lines on top of the meat in a vertical pattern, taking care that each is spaced about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from each other. Afterward, repeat the process with diagonal lines in the opposite direction to create a crosshatch pattern. Penetrate the meat about ⁄8 to ⁄4 inch (0.32 to 0.64 cm) with each cut.

procedure.summary: Rub salt and oil into the scored area of the pork leg.
procedure.description: Pour your 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of oil over the scored area followed by 1 teaspoon (5.69 grams) of sea salt. Use a basting brush to brush the oil and salt across the scored surface of the meat, making sure that it's covered as evenly as possible. Make sure there aren't any clumps or patches of salt or oil concentrated to one area. Use a silicone basting brush for the best results.

procedure.summary: Roast your pork leg at 465 °F (241 °C) for 25 minutes.
procedure.description: Place your roasting pan onto the top oven rack. Keep the oven door closed and don't open it until 25 minutes has passed. After 25 minutes, check the skin to make sure it is crisp and golden in color. If it isn't, continue roasting your pork leg in 5- to 10-minute intervals until it is.

procedure.summary: Reduce the temperature to 355 °F (179 °C) and continue roasting for about 1 hour.
procedure.description: After reducing the temperature, continue roasting the pork leg for 30 minutes per 2.2 pounds (1.00 kg). In this case, the pork leg is 4.4 pounds (2.0 kg), which means you should cook it for another 1 hour. Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the pork—it should read 160 °F (71 °C) when the pork is done. If you like your pork a bit crispy, cook it for 35 minutes per 2.2 pounds (1.00 kg), which is another 1 hour and 10 minutes for a 4.4 lb (2.0 kg) roast.

procedure.summary: Cool your pork leg for 10 minutes and serve.
procedure.description: Remove the roasting pan from the oven, cover it with aluminum foil, and let it sit. Once it has cooled, slice it into 1 to 2 inch (2.5 to 5.1 cm) pieces and serve it with your choice of sides—pumpkin, roasted potato, steamed vegetables, apple jelly, and gravy are all great choices. Store your leftover pork covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 2 to 3 months.
